II. Purpose of Addendum
The facility wants to add the McCullough Home to the license and increase the
capacity of the license by six. This program will service co-ed youth between the
ages of 6-17 years old with intellectual developmental disabilities and cognitive
impairments.
III. Methodology
01/25/2022- Inspection Completed- Fire Safety- A Rating
03/18/2022- Application Received- request to Add McCullough Home to the license
and add six beds to the license capacity.
05/09/2022- Inspection Completed- Env. Health- A Rating
05/09/2022- Document Received- Program Statement Draft, Policy Drafts, and new
job description
07/26/2022- Inspection Completed- On-Site- McCullough Home toured
08/22/2022- Document Received- Finalized Program Statement and Policy/
Procedures
IV. Description of Findings and Conclusions
Physical Description of Facility
McCullough Home is an additional building located on the St. John’s Home
Residential Campus off of Knapp Street in Grand Rapids, Michigan. Upon entering
the main door there is a mudroom/ waiting area to the second door to lead you into
the main home. Once you enter the main door, there is a large milieu area where
there are tables for the youth to use for mealtimes and activities. The milieu also
includes two couches and a TV that is mounted to the wall. This area has multiple
windows that allows natural light into the open area. There is a bookshelf with age
appropriate and developmental level books and activities. Off of the milieu there is
an open kitchen area where meals will be prepared for the home. The kitchen area
has a working refrigerator, dishwasher, sink, microwave, and stove. There is a
food pantry with dry goods. The kitchen area has safety locks on the cabinets
noted for spices, pots, pans, and breakable objects. There is a home phone
located within the kitchen area that gives access for youth to make approved
phone calls. To the right of the kitchen there is locked room that has the locked
medication cart and the washer and dryer. This allows the medications to be
doubled locked. Across the hall from the laundry room is the locked staff
bathroom/staff office. This room will be used for staff to put their personal items,
lock up items that youth cannot have access to, such as sharp knives.
Within the main level of the home, there are two hallways designated for sleeping
areas for the youth. To the left of the milieu there is one hallway that has three
single bedrooms, three single bathrooms, and three rooms designated to be each
2

youth’s own sensory rooms. To the right of the milieu there this another hallway
that has three single bedrooms, three single bathrooms, and three rooms
designated to be each youth’s own sensory rooms. Each bedroom has a twin size
bed, desk and closet for the youth. Each youth will have their own bathroom that
has their own toilet and bath/shower. There is one bathroom that is equipped for
handicap needs. The sensory rooms are designated for each youth to use for their
personal needs. Each hallway has an emergency exit door.
Off of the milieu there is access to the basement area of the home. This access is
has a gate blocking access to the basement stairs. Once you walk down the stairs
there is a locked door. When you enter the basement to the right there is locked
office areas where youth personal files will be kept and staff offices such as the
program supervisor’s office. To the right of the basement stairs there is an open
milieu area that the youth will have extra space to perform activities. There is a
bathroom downstairs that youth will have access to when utilizing this area. The
basement area has large window areas to bring in natural light and there are two
exit doors. Outside the home there is a mini basketball court for youth to have
access to.
Program Description
McCullough House is a 6-bed open, community- based facility providing
comprehensive services to youth in a home-like setting. The program will support
youth between the ages of 11-17 with developmental disabilities, defined as an
individual diagnosed with a mental disorder which significantly impacts their
adaptive functioning and ability to care for themselves and generally is considered
a lifelong consideration. Youth admitted to this program must demonstrate, within
the last six months, a responsiveness to redirection around de-escalation. IQ
testing results must indicate an IQ score of 45-69 to be eligible for this program.
Youth with additional complex medical needs would be assessed to determine if
the program could safely support the referred youth. Youth in this program will be
involved with MDHHS or Adoption Subsidy.
Upon admission, an initial assessment will occur within 30-days to determine
treatment needs and types of intervention most beneficial for the youth. The facility
will utilize a multidisciplinary approach throughout treatment which includes
medical, psychiatric, therapeutic, and case management services in addition to
24/7 supervision and care. Youth will be provided weekly individual therapy,
specialized group therapy or intensive activity-based therapy. Adjunct therapy will
include Occupational Therapy, Physical Therapy, Speech Therapy and Applied
Behavioral Analysis is provided and/or coordinated as the treatment plan
indicates. Discharge planning begins on the day of admission with a goal of
discharge within a nine-month time frame and to a less restrictive setting than an
open, non-secure, residential treatment program. Discharge and after care
services are developed and organized in collaboration with the youth’s MDHHS or
private agency worker and treatment team.
3

Psychiatric services are contracted through Pine Rest Christian Mental Health
Services and or/ Hope Network. A Board-Certified Child Psychiatrist provides care
to the youth placed at the facility. Health Services are overseen by a Registered
Nurse with support from licensed medical providers, on site, in addition to medical
care coordinated through Spectrum Health Adolescent Clinic, located in Grand
Rapids, MI. Educational Services are provided through the Kent Intermediate
School District and/or Grand Rapids Public schools and are coordinated and
overseen by St. John’s residential case managers.
The staff-to-resident ratio is 1:2 during waking hours and 1:4 during sleeping
hours. The facility will have no form of seclusions for the residents. Facility staff
will be trained in the use of AEGIS system training for de-escalation and
emergency restraint purposes. The AEGIS System focuses on prevention of
dysregulation in youth and provides for the least restrictive therapeutic holds when
there is an emergency restraint needed.
V. Recommendation
I recommend that the McCullough Home be added to the St. John’s Home
Residential License and the license to have an increased capacity to 46.
